values: Not that I have anything to add today, but I got another random spam reply in an old post, which brought me back here. Lots of people still posting, so I'll probably put LJ back on my daily read schedule again.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/45751.html
Well, the account still exists, just didn't realize it had been so long since I had a post. Maybe I'll come back later with a broom to sweep out some of the cobwebs.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/45331.html

This caught me a bit off guard. I'm used to seeing spam in E-mail and even the occasional text, but on a year and a half old LJ post? And it's not even that good of a spam post. There's no link in the post so apparently, I'm supposed to copy and paste into Google and look for it myself. I wouldn't click on a random spam link anyway, so that's really asking a lot of me. The broken English isn't very entertaining even though its trying to pretend to be asking for help in a post. I'm giving it an F- because lack of a link is spam failure and I can't even get a good laugh out of the post.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/45091.html

I'm not entirely sure what I think about this. P4CM stands for Passion for Christ Movement. Fine, another religious movement to go along with the hundreds of others and they haven't actually done anything to aggravate me (aside from substituting the number "4" for the word "for" God, I hate that. The only place that should be done is on a license plate.) But they sell t-shirts with "ex-whatever" written on them. I'm vaguely amused at the idea of wearing one ironically. (Though the ex-fornicator one would be true enough, I am married.) I think the ex-masturbater needs to have "but really frustrated" in small print beneath it. There's an ex-homosexual shirt that I started to rant about, but decided that I was putting way more thought into it than it deserved. Functioning brain cells are at a premium and there's more important I could be burning brain power on.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/44885.html
Mark that as another seal of the Apocalypse broken. Patrick Thomas... 10:26pm 6lbs, 12 oz.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/44581.html

I'm finding that, aside from having a completely idiotic name, facebook does have a couple of neat features. Mainly the quick status update. Doesn't require the commitment that livejournal seems to demand. I always feel like I have to write something somewhat substantial here. I know I don't have to, but I don't update all that often and it is primarily a writing journal, I feel like I'm short-changing you if I don't put in enough. At the same time, there's more to Facebook than the status update so it's more useful than Twitter. I'm not sure I understand Twitter. Do people really want to see the random thoughts that go through my mind? If I tweeted (good god, can we come up with new media jargon that doesn't sound retarded?)I'm pretty sure we'd end up with something like this. I"m kinda getting into the scramble game on Facebook. I'm not too sure about most of the games on there, but scramble is keeping my interest for now.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/44538.html

As a good chunk of you already know, I got a Facebook account. I hadn't planned on it. I barely update this as it is, do I really need another account to ignore? My firend Deni sent me an inite and I hardly ever talk to her, so any way to keep up with her is a good. (Apparently, Seo sent me an invite way back when, but I don't recall it.) It's interesting playing with the new account, though, finding all the people I had lost contact with and seeing how everybody's connected. My E-mail has been a flurry of requests, confirmations, and comments. (My Email's also forwarded to my phone and set to vibrate. Almost wanted to just leave it my pocket all evening.)

Not sure how much I'll keep up with it. It's keeping me busy for now. If you have a Facebook account and I didn't send a request, look me up, I probably just haven't found you yet.

I promised a kitty photo, too. Paige has taken a bunch of picture, I just haven't pulled the card from the camera yet.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/44226.html

Thanks for the help, guys, especially Seo... that link is very useful...

Now for the bitching...

Who the hell thought this was a good idea? If I wanted to talk to random people, I'd go to a chatroom. Let's yank two screennames out of the eather with no explanation and see if we can get them to chat. Whee...isn't this fun? No?

Now that I'm clued in, though, at least I'll be able alleviate confusion on the other side if this happens again. But still, what a dumb idea...

And I'm still annoyed at Mr (Ms?) 2-minutes-till-I-block-you. I can barely get a coherent thought formed in two minutes, let alone type it out. I didn't spam or make a lewd suggestion or anything that would warrant a blocking. (Although all that blocked was a random botname.) This person didn't stick around long enough to find out what going on and is more than likely get hit again and irritate some other poor random person and block yet another botname. It's a vicious cycle.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/44006.html
Happy Thanksgiving! (or as the rest of the world calls it... Thursday.)
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/43578.html

HardcoreCoho (1:02:11 AM): Hi.

Arsayalalyur (1:06:28 AM): mornin'

HardcoreCoho (1:07:17 AM): telling me who you might be before i block you might be a brilliant idea.

Arsayalalyur (1:07:59 AM): actually I got IM'd by you first...

HardcoreCoho (1:08:40 AM): not tonight. and i dont remember. you have 2 minutes my friend.

Arsayalalyur (1:11:45 AM): Look, I don't know what happened... I got IM'd by you at 1:02:11. all it said was "Hi." I was trying to figure out if you were somebody I knew. But I guessing not, judging from the hostility.

Arsayalalyur (1:13:13 AM): My name's Nick, I'm in Kinderhook, NY.

Arsayalalyur (1:13:39 AM): Or did I get blocked already?

So, I'm guessing I got blocked. But damn, I didn't even get a chance to figure out what was going on. Anybody out there know this screenname? If so, kindly point out that I'm not a weird random stalker and if they'd been slightly more personable, we both could've figured this out.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/43406.html

Actually, I hate cat memes. But it seemed appropriate to use since Paige picked up a new kitten over the weekend. A little female tabby-Siamese mix. White with brownish stripes at the ears, tail and feet. Cute cat. 

The biggest problem so far is that, being part siamese, she's really vocal and being three months old, she's kinda whiny. Phaedra isn't all that happy about sharing the house with another cat, so she's whining. And my son's teething, so he's whining. And I'm getting kinda whiny cause the three of them are whining at me. bah.

I'll post a picture when Paige finally gets around to taking one of the cat.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/43016.html

Eion got his first haircut this weekend. Now he looks more like a little boy. Now I'm just waiting for him to increase his vocabulary and we can shed that whole toddler thing a year or two early.

I was changing him the other day and I noticed two slightly disturbing tags on his clothing. One was "fire resistant fabric" while the other informed that it wasn't fire resistant. I can't think of a scenario where I would need to know whether my child's will burn or not that doesn't involve a Bavarian witch, a gingerbread house and an oven. My flight suit is made of nomex because there is a slightly higher chance of being caught in a flaming wreck in the unlikely event I survive a place crash than normal. (It protects everything but my head and face. I'm not reassured by this.)
But my son isn't going have to deal with fire on daily basis, much less roll around in it. Might as well tell me how acid resistant it is or include nutritional content of the fibers.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/42773.html

I've been home since Sunday and actually off active duty since Thursday. (The New England Air Show was this weekend and I worked medical support for it.) I was on Alert status all week, which is sort of like being under paid house arrest (with crappy cable channel selection and no internet access) I just can't seem to actually deploy for anything. The McGuire crew that was supposed to pick us up didn't finish getting people out until 4am on Monday, so it's not like they couldn't have used us. Part of the issue was getting us down to Little Rock for Staging, McGuire has c-130's, Westover doesn't. (Taking a C-5 would've been nice but for just two crews and equipment it's hard to justify the cost of flying one. Plus we'd need two C-130's when we got down there... or C-17's, KC-135's, CH-53's, Blackhawks, pretty much anything but a C-5.)
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/42689.html

So I get this call at 10:30 on Sat. Need to pull a flight crew together ASAP in preparation of Hurricane Gustav. After a quick talk with Paige over logistics of me leaving last minute, she grudgingly gave me the okay to go. We're camping at Hunter's this year with the baby and it's been interesting. (More on that later, if I remember) Give a quick call back to my unit to say "Yeah, I'm available, I'll be there as soon as I can." (Which turned out to be later than expected because the village of Chatham had shut down all access to the Taconic Parkway due to a parade and my choices were wait out the parade or drive back through Kinderhook. Same amount of time either way. I chose to wait out the parade.)

I got to Westover and went through the flurry of paperwork for deployment. And then everything came to full stop while the Air Force figured out how to get us to Little Rock. Long story short, they changed their minds about six million times and I'm still sitting at Westover waiting to hear if they are going to send us down after the fact or say "thanks for playing" and send me home. 

More to come as I find out...
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/42309.html
Aimed mostly at . Michael Phelps returns to his tank at Sea World.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/42218.html

<lj user="dwarven_brewer"> had his take on the Summer Olympics which reminded me of my own thoughts that were churning. None my thoughts are really original, as I'm sure that countless other people have had the same thoughts since the Olympics started.

A lot has to do with some of the events that are considered sports. Like beach volley ball and badminton. These are barely sports, anything that's played in my backyard during a barbecue should not be in the Olympics. There should be beer, overcooked hamburgers, undercooked hotdogs, and alcoholic relatives who may or may not be angry drunks. Conversely, if the IOC includes these "sports," why not include horseshoes or bocce? Hell, lawn darts, I'd love to be able to buy a set of lawn darts again. (My grandmother used to have a set, but I didn't get the chance to ask her about them before she moved to VA.)

I wanted to watch a badminton match, just to see how it was played at the Olympic level, but it's a hard game to find. I dvr'd a 6 hour block that was supposed to include badminton, but the bulk of it was track events, specifically the marathon. It's impressive to be able to run that far that fast, but man, is it boring to watch. I ff'd through all of that, until the equestrian events, which Paige wanted to watch and then I lost interest. I'll have to check it out online or something.

Water-polo? Why not turn it into real polo and add horses. Be a lot more interesting than what it is now.

Table Tennis? Ping-pong, I can play in my basement. I know the Chinese are proud that they're really good at it, but I'll start showing interest when they can beat the US foosball team. And where is my Olympic air hockey? How about darts? or arcade golf or mini golf. (I wonder what the Swedish women's mini-putt team looks like.) What's the criteria for Olympic sports? Could we see Olympic chess? Checkers? Backgammon? How about Chutes and Ladders or Candyland? How much money do I have to toss at the IOC to get Go Fish as an Olympic sport
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/41800.html

Maybe it's 'cause the Marines like a challenge or just like to cause trouble, but they set up a recruiting station in Berkeley. And, of course, the hippies come out to protest. The Daily Show sent out Rob Riggle, who is also a Major in the USMCR to find out what all the trouble was


<lj-embed id="1"/>

Don't get me wrong, I'm all for free love and no wars (less free love and more no wars since the whole marriage thing) but let's be realistic here. Somebody has to protect those unwilling to fight for themselves. (Sorta reminds me of the irony of burning an American flag in protest. You're burning a symbol of the very thing that gives you the right to protest against it, meaning you don't actually want that right of protest, otherwise you wouldn't protesting against it. And now my head's spinning...)

I just feel bad for the poor recruiter trying to meet his quota.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/41592.html

There's a nifty little exercise happening in Tunisia later this year. But they're taking applications from almost the entire Air Force Reserve and the application included an essay on why I should be selected to go to Tunisia. I hate essay questions, particularly the ones where I have to present myself like this. I spent all day Sunday at drill trying to write the stupid thing. Sadly, my ego does not extend to making myself look good on paper. I got it written and turned in after sign out. Hopefully, it's not as painful to read as it was to write. 

The one thing on the application that might help get me get selected is unfortunately something I loathe more than writing about myself: NBC (Nuclear, Biological, and Chemical Warfare or CBRNE, as the Air Force calls it, adding Radiological and explosives to the acronym. Seems a bit redundant to me.) I'm glad I got the training, but it's really a huge pain in the ass to deal with. And the thought of spending ten days in North Africa decontaminating simulations really doesn't thrill. It's hot in the suits, difficult to drink water, you can't eat (or pee or anything else you would normally unzip for) and everything else is made 8x more cumbersome. 

In short, I have a decent chance of being selected, but it'll probably be for something I dislike. I have a very slim chance of being selected for Air Evac, which is something I enjoy. Oh, well, I'll try to remember to keep things posted as I find out.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/41237.html
For you language geeks with way too much time on your hands, I give you... William Shakespeare's Pulp Fiction
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/40966.html

Well, it's really more of a rocker, actually. But the Air Force has decided that maybe I am promotable after all. So now I'm going to be E-5 Staff Sargent (E-4 used to be Sargent in the Air Force and parts of the DOD are still confused about what my actual rank was at E-4. Probably has something to do with how wrong it feels to move from being a Corporal to Senior Airman)

The last time I was promoted was in April of 2000. Yeah, 8 years. Most people do their entire military service in that time, including the Inactive Ready Reserve, where you get to sit at home, fat and happy, praying that WWIII doesn't break out (or invade yet another country before we finish mucking about in the first two. Although, between stop-loss and deployments that extend contracts I don't think there are too many people sitting IRR right now anyway) Hell, my time with the Marines fits nicely within that time frame. (In reality, there's some overlap, since I didn't get out until Dec 2002.) I just happy to finally get my NCO status back. At least the time to E-6 (Tech Sargent) is only a year to a year and a half. 

Coinciding with the promotion, the Air Force has decided that after 4 years of training, I should actually get to do my job. I'll be in Germany for a week in May preparing to fly patients back to Andrews AFB. I'm happy about since it's what I joined up to do. There's also possible deployments coming down the line for the fall, so we'll see what kind of fun times that brings.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/40871.html

On Saturday, I took Paige down to NY to see Spamalot. (Awesome show, it's got Clay Aiken as Sir Robin.) We had some extra time after lunch before show, so we wandered about Times Square. (The Hershey Store is selling green tea filled chocolate which is...um, different...) We passed by a gentlemen's club that advertised steak and sushi. My question is, would you really want to go into a gentlemen's club that smelled of raw fish?
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/40530.html

Came across this in my meanderings about the web. Missed this one when it hit the paper and apparently it's now censored in reprints. (Or so I'm told, anyway... I can't even find a reprint online to check, and I don't know what book it would be in to check... the strip's from April of 2005 if somebody with better research skills wants to try.)
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/40379.html

But I did own a '79 Trans Am at one point in my life. Olds 403 engine, The car went fast. I mean, really fast. How fast? Honestly, I don't know. For some reason the speedometer only went to 100 mph. Fast enough, though. I managed to beat a motorcycle with it. (Through sheer luck and the stupidity of the rider. He mis-shifted somehow and just disappeared from my mirror.) Where am I going with this? Well, YearOne decided for the 30th anniversary of Smokey and the Bandit they would release this. It's completely ridiculous, way too expensive and I'm planning to add it to my Amazon wish list. Anybody got a couple hundred thousand dollars to spare?
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/40012.html

We've been blowing raspberries at each other. Granted, his are mostly him sticking out his tongue and grunting around it or blowing a couple bubbles, but he's three months old and it's only the first day. He did have a few that were more or less genuine raspberries. 
I'm pretty blown away by the fact that he's actually attempting to imitate me. If this keeps up, I'll have him giving the Bronx Cheer by the end of next week.
He also like to stand (as apposed to laying on his tummy, which he hates.) This is complicated by the fact that he doesn't quite have kneecaps, but I may be in trouble once they're fully developed and he has the leg strength to keep himself up. My niece was walking at 8 months and as proud as I would be if he could walk that early, I'm not really looking forward to walking at all. It adds a whole new dimension of responsibility. I can't just lay him on the rug for second while I try to locate the remote. (TV is something we're trying not get him hooked on. I understand being fascinated with the bright changing light and sound, but he won't do much else but stare at the TV if it's on. A three month old couch potato, go figure.) Once he's mobile, I know the second I turn my attention from him, he'll be getting into trouble.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/39755.html

Well, the new computer is up and running... but I sorta feel like I've bought a Sega 32X after the Sega Saturns had already come out.
I'm running Windows XPx64 (I have 64bit dual core processor. It runs nice.) But now that Windows Vista is out (in more flavors than Baskin Robbins, both 32 and 64 bit) there isn't a whole lot of support for XPx64. (Not that there was much to begin with.)Hell, Most programs don't even know what OS I'm even running. Mostly I get Win 2000 or Server 2003. At least it's still recognizable as Windows and I'm not getting anything freaky like MacOSX or Ubuntu. 

The whole reason I upgraded was to play Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion. But it turns out that there's an issue between Nvidia graphics cards and Oblivion. That was a headache and a half worth of tweaking and downloading and I'm still not sure what I did exactly, but now it only crashes when I exit the game. Somehow, in the course of actually trying to get the game to work, I ended up with the game playing on the second monitor. I've tried telling windows to disable the #2 monitor, but the game then tells me that it can't find a certain parameter to play. My quick fix is to simply switch which is the mian monitor while playing, but I'd like to try to have this fixed permanently. Any thoughts from the peanut gallery?
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/39567.html

I bet if you made a placenta meat sauce you wouldn't even notice the placenta. Well, except for maybe the chewy bits. Yeah, so my son was born yesterday at 1247. 7lbs 11oz and 20 1/4 inches. No, we didn't eat the placenta. There wasn't any place to cook it and those things taste nasty raw. I wasn't planning taking any pictures during delivery (Paige would have killed me) but I had to get a picture of the "no photos" sign. His name is Eion Malik. Eion is Gaelic for John and pronounced "e-Yahn" Malik is my Grandmother's family name. (The Russian side of the family, where he's Great-grandchild #11) *Edit: Those photos are HUGE!! Sometime later I'm going to come back and reduce them somehow. Don't no how, yet (thumbnails, maybe) But for now you're just going to have to deal with giant baby pictures.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/39309.html

Stupid instructions...in a pouch on the underside of the mattress platform. The pouch was attached with hard plastic zip ties. I just figured they were there so the instructions didn't get lost. Nope. The pouch has all sorts of dire warnings on it about the bad things that can happen if you misuse the crib. And written in big bold red letters DO NOT REMOVE THIS POUCH. Just in case you forget and need to be reminded.

DO NOT use the mattress platform as a side rail. I don't even think it would fit that way. But apparently somebody tried...

DO NOT use if parts are missing. Hmmm, maybe the drywall screw I was gonna use to replace that missing bolt might not be such a good idea...

DO NOT place near windows where cords from drapes or blinds may strangle child. If this isn't obvious, parenting may not be for you.

Only use non-toxic finish specified for children's products. Odd, no bold face. Sadly, I guess I can't use that old can of lead paint I found at my grandmothers.

DO NOT use a water mattress with this crib Who the hell give their infant a water bed?

I can see this journal turning into the misadventures of fatherhood. I don't know when I'll post again and I apologize for the huge gap since the last post. At some point maybe I'll get around to posting why. (It's not just from having zero time due to impending baby.)
Maybe I'll find out how to post pictures by the time the kid's born to share with you.

***EDIT*** Well, duh! There's a nice little button near the top of the edit window that's labeled "Insert Image" Gosh, I wonder what that does? Let's test it: Sweet! It works! That was taken back on March 21. He's much bigger now.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/39006.html

Paige woke up suddenly and wanted me to look up Equine Herpes Virus type I. I didn't even know Horses could get herpes. (Apparently, cows, too.) There was an out break in Florida last week and bunch of horses died. It was from a European horse that traveled through NY and she was worried that it could get passed on to her horses via one of us if we could be carriers. (Most likely her, since I don't go to horse shows that often.) But lo and behold, EHV-1 is only transmitted from horse to horse. 

Other news... last Friday Paige got to hear the heartbeat of the little spud. (Trying to think of an endearing nickname other than to keep calling it "Fetus." Something that hasn't been used yet. People keep wanting to use "Spawn." But We're not fish, dammit!) No ultrasound yet, not till February, I guess. I have to wait another month before I know what the sex is. 

And awhile back I asked you guys for words. You guys gave me a bunch of good ones. Well, the words were for a card game I'm working on and I finally got to play test it on Thursday. It still needs a bit of work and I'll be updating progress on this as it comes along. My goal is to get it into a  "fine tuning" by Genericon. Doubt I'll make it, but maybe I'll get close.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/38901.html

Leeched from (From last week sometime, but I've been lazy and just read it today)
On the twelfth day of Christmas, Arsayalalyur sent to me...
Twelve fionamorgan24s drumming
Eleven marnens piping
Ten madhattes a-leaping
Nine sskipstress dancing
Eight thursdayschilds a-milking
Seven petrasdreamings a-swimming
Six kyrenes a-laying
Five co-o-o-ollwens
Four hotspurres
Three demoncallers
Two auto-fellating unicorns
...and a LiveJournal meme in a pear tree.
Get your own Twelve Days:
Let's break this down a bit so I can explain at least one of those: 12: okay, well, didn't know she drummed, but nothing odd about that 11: er, close... should be fiddler's fiddling. (fiddling's such a goofy word) 10: His head, it blots out the sun. It's like an eclipse. (Inside joke that where 'Hatte's the only on here that'll get it.) 9: Have actually seen dancing. Though if I saw nine of her, I must've been pretty drunk. 8: Milking? Okay, I could use some more milk. (Paige baked a ton of cookies this year and I ran out of milk eating them.) 7: It's a writing journal, how it's swimming, I don't know. 6: Heh, that sound's so dirty. 5: Any other other name probably would've worked, but the meme had to go and grab the one of the few two syllable names on my list. (And I keep thinking "with rings on her fingers and bells on her toes." I cannot remember what nursery rhyme that comes from.) 4: I read this and I see Dan as the four kings in a card deck. Don't know why. Maybe it's the beard. 3: Jen's cool, we need to have more of her around. 2: Not that I have any real desire to see auto-fellating unicorns, but it was something that I saw in somebody else's LJ that I thought was bizarre and twisted enough to be an interest. (And now I have two of them.) 1: We should be so lucky to only have one LJ meme. (But then, what would 3/4 of the people on LJ post about?)

My clever plan to tunnel to Singapore is slightly flawed. Guess I'll have to get that quantum teleporter tuned up instead.

The $199 HD-DVD Player for the X-Box 360? Yeah, it'll run on Windows. Macs, too, if someone releases an HD-DVD driver for it. You'll need a program that can interpret the disks, (the site recommends WinDVD8) and download a diver, but a it's a cheap HD-DVD player. Also, before I forget, Thanks to all for the congrats about the baby. I'd do it all individually, but I'm too tired to be witty. and just saying thanks 20 times gets a bit boring.

Paige had a doctors appointment today to confirm what the store bought tests were showing and yep, she's pregnant. While I realize that this is the equivalent of standing on top of a building with megaphone, we're are trying to keep this low-key, mostly so that she can surprise our parents with framed sonograms. So don't go mentioning this to any relatives, namely my sister. Not that any of you speak to any of my relatives, but you know just in case. Paige has an OB-GYN appointment next weekend and I'll be putting up more updates as they come in.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/37440.html

Yeah, I know, but everybody else is doing Halloween, Samhain,All Hollow's eve and what have you, sO I just had to be different. Plus I'm kinda curious as to what we're actually supposed to for All Saints Day. I know it was supposed to be a response to Halloween. I'm trying to figure how this was marketed to pagans. "No, no, it's like Samwain, just you don't dress up as demons or play with gourds or get any treats or get to play any tricks. You get to... uh...dress up as your favorite Saint and...um, here have a communion wafer." This would explain why All Saints Day seems to be marginalized, while Halloween is still pretty popular. But which Saint would I dress up as? Has Mother Theresa been canonized, yet? I bet I can get a nun costume pretty cheap today. Barring that, I guess Our Lady of Blessed Acceleration. Not really a saint, huh? Damn, St Cristopher, then.
Or I can take the easy way out like I always do with my Halloween costumes and go as St Nicholas.
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/37121.html

It seems that every time I use go into the bathroom at work Niel Diamond is playing on Muzak (playing over the phone's speaker in the bathroom, which is another rant entirely) It's almost always, but not every time, "Sweet Caroline." I think Muzak is either sending me a message, or really needs to add a few more selections to their library. (Wish I could select the Muzak channel we had down in Florida. That one played "Born to be Wild.)
http://arsayalalyur.livejournal.com/37053.html

Usually my spam contains sentences yanked from literature or complete nonsense. This one is really odd. I mean it's in English, but when you read it, it's like channeling Louis Carroll. All it's missing is a couple of made up words. First thing I got was: The highly paid hydrogen atom Which I thought was a bit odd, but then it turned into a normal spam with an for buying stock in an ethanol company. But after the ad it turned really amusing: A stoic turkey reads a magazine, and a blithe spirit panics; however, the mysterious skyscraper writes a love letter to another turn signal. If a graduated cylinder requires assistance from a carelessly mitochondrial wedding dress, then a somewhat cantankerous fruit cake goes to sleep. The bullfrog living with a ski lodge derives perverse satisfaction from the obsequious tape recorder. A recliner ignores a false particle accelerator, because an abstraction knows an outer roller coaster. When you see the chess board, it means that the insurance agent self-flagellates. A warranty If the minivan about a pine cone usually competes with a mortician over the support group, then a skyscraper hides. Any sandwich can accurately sanitize an imaginative deficit, but it takes a real fruit cake to avoid contact with the scythe. But it's a car and it's brand spanking new. I mean, the seats are still shiny. 4 of the 34 miles that were on it when I bought it, Paige and I put on it while test driving it. It's a white 2006 Hyundai Elantra with a 5-speed manual transmission. The stick shift was a bitch to find. Turns out, it was one of only two new cars on the lot and the other one was an extremley low end base model with no options what so ever. No a/c, or power anything(I think you had to start it by pushing off with your feet and yelling "Yabba-Dabba-Doo!") Doesn't anybody drive standard anymore?

I had been planning on saving my pennies and buying a VW Jetta TDI in a few years, but my Explorer decided that reverse was no longer a necessary gear. (Reverse, Neutral and Drive all pushed the car forward.) The Jetta was about 10k more than I could afford right now. (Not to mention that you can't even buy diesel vehicles in NY right now. Not only that, if you could get a new diesel, you wouldn't be able to put fuel in it right now. I'm not entirely sure why, but all the pumps have these stickers saying that the diesel may wreck the engines of all 2007 and newer vehicles. I think it has something to do with low-sulfur diesel not being sold in NY yet.)

Yeah...

So I was in a bit of rush out the door last night heading off to work and put my glass of raspberry iced tea in the refrigerator. Paige made stuffed peppers last night. The glass spent all night uncovered in the fridge. This morning after I came home from work, I was treated to pepper flavored raspberry tea. It doesn't taste anywhere near as yummy as you'd think.

and I probably should add that I'm finally gainfully employed in Columbia County as a 911 dispatcher. So don't do anything stupid to sheep between the hours 7pm and 7am out here, okay. Save that stuff for lunch while I'm sleeping. However, if you're in dire need of help while lost in banjo country (there's a lot of it out here, too) I'll be the calm reassuring voice on the other end of the phone. (Yes, I was able to type that with a straight face. The peppered rapberry tea helped.)

Oddly enough, as rural as this area is, we haven't had any thresher accidents called in. Harvest hasn't started, but I was sure we'd get at least one during my first week on the job. Hell, the Columbia County Fair is going on this week, and there hasn't been one drunken carny incident. I'm kinda disappointed.
